Open table in a new tab Constructs were linearized after the termination codon, then transcribed using T7, T3, or SP6 RNA polymerase and the Stratagene RNA mCAP kit according to manufacturer's instructions. Translation was performed using rabbit reticulocyte lysate (Promega), labeling with 3H-leucine in the presence of canine pancreatic microsomes (Promega) as described previously by Abell et al. (14Abell B.M. Holbrook L.A. Abenes M. Murphy D.J. Hills M.J. Moloney M.M. Plant Cell. 1997; 9: 1481-1493Crossref PubMed Scopus (141) Google Scholar). Microsomes were recovered by dilution of the translation mix to 100 μl with 10% sucrose and centrifuged at 213,000 × g in an ultracentrifuge (TL100, Beckman, Mississauga, Ontario, Canada) using a TLA100.2 rotor for 20 min at 4 °C. Proteinase K treatments were performed by addition of the enzyme (50 μg ml−1) directly to translation reactions on ice for 30 min. For Triton X-100 controls, TX100 was added to 1% (w/v) prior to proteinase K addition. Proteinase K was inactivated by addition of phenylmethylsulfonyl fluoride to a concentration of 5 mm. Pelleted microsomes were resuspended in 20 μl of 100 mmNa2CO3 and incubated on ice for 15 min. Membrane-associated polypeptides were separated by repelleting as before but with no additional buffer. 3H-labeled polypeptides were solubilized in loading buffer and boiled for 3 min then separated by SDS-PAGE on a 16% acrylamide gel, according to Schagger et al. (33Schagger H. von Jagow G. Biochem. 1987; 166: 368-379Google Scholar). Gels were fixed and visualized by fluorography using Amplify (Amersham Biosciences), according to the manufacturer's instructions. Molecular masses were determined by comparison to prestained markers (Bio-Rad), which in turn were calibrated from a plot generated by Sigma 2.5–17-kDa and Pharmacia 14–94-kDa markers. In stage 1, translation was performed for 45 min, substituting microsomes, RNA, or both with an equivalent volume of water. The total volume of 17.5 μl allowed for further additions to complete a 20-μl reaction. The translation reaction was then incubated with 1.25 mmcycloheximide or puromycin on ice for 15 min. The posttranslation in stage 2 was incubated for 75 min with the addition of microsomes, RNA, or both to yield a final volume of 20 μl. The SRP receptor was disrupted by incubating microsomes with 5 μg ml−1 trypsin on ice for 60 min. The protease was inactivated by addition of 100 μg ml−1 soybean trypsin inhibitor and incubated on ice for a further 15 min. The microsomes were added to a translation reaction, with either SRα RNA, or water for the control. A full complement of amino acids was used instead of the normal radiolabeling mixture. The microsomes were recovered by pelleting, then resuspended in buffer (25 mm TEA-OAc, pH 7.5, 1 mm dithiothreitol, 0.25m sucrose). The resultant microsomes were used at the standard concentration for subsequent test translations. Microsomes were recovered after translation by pelleting. Each 10-μl translation was resuspended in 100 μl of buffer, pH 7.5 (85 mm K-Bicine, pH 11.0, 150 mm PIPES-Cl, pH 6.5), pH 11 (100 mm K-Bicine, pH 11.0), or pH 11.4 (100 mmNa2CO3). After a 30-min incubation on ice, samples to be protease-treated were supplemented with 50 μg ml−1 proteinase K, incubated on ice for a further 5 min, and then neutralized to pH 7.5 with 18 μl of 1 m PIPES-Cl pH 6.5. All samples were immediately pelleted and resuspended in loading buffer supplemented with 10 mm phenylmethylsulfonyl fluoride. Evidence to date suggests that oleosins are integrated into ER membranes co-translationally, following a SRP- and Sec61-dependent pathway (27Qu R. Wang S. Lin Y. Vance V.B. Huang A.H.C. Biochem. J. 1986; 235: 57-65Crossref PubMed Scopus (73) Google Scholar, 28Thoyts P.J.E. Millichip M.I. Stobart A.K. Griffiths W.T. Shewry P.R. Napier J.A. Plant Mol. Biol. 1995; 29: 403-410Crossref PubMed Scopus (50) Google Scholar, 29Beaudoin F. Wilkinson B.M. Stirling C. Napier J.A. Plant J. 2000; 23: 159-170Crossref PubMed Google Scholar,34Hills M.J. Watson M.D. Murphy D.J. Hills M.J. Watson M.D. Murphy D.J. Planta. 1993; 189: 24-29Crossref PubMed Scopus (55) Google Scholar). To place oleosin topology in context, we needed to define the targeting pathway of oleosin into our experimental system of canine pancreatic membrane. Since we needed to differentiate between co- and posttranslational membrane integration, we experimentally separated the translation and membrane-insertion steps. Hence, microsomes were added after halting translation with either cycloheximide (inhibits chain extension) or puromycin (releases nascent polypeptide chains from the ribosomes). The ability of the translation machinery to withstand the preincubation was verified by providing a control sample with oleosin message at the postincubation stage. Proteinase K treatment ensured detection of true membrane-integrated fragments. Fig.2 A shows that oleosin was unable to associate significantly with microsomes posttranslationally when either cycloheximide (Fig. 2 A, lane 2) or puromycin (Fig. 2 A, lane 6) were used, as compared with cotranslational microsomal addition (Fig. 2 A,lanes 1 and 5) or postincubation without the addition of inhibitors (Fig. 2 A, lanes 4 and8). The ability of cycloheximide and puromycin to inhibit translation was confirmed (Fig. 2 A, lanes 3 and7). The low level of oleosin targeting after cycloheximide treatment (Fig. 2 A, lane 2) is probably due to ribosome-dependent posttranslational translocation. These results support a cotranslational pathway and lead to a more precise characterization of the ER targeting pathway. We next investigated whether oleosin uses a classical SRP-mediated targeting pathway by a sensitive assay that uses the ablation and reconstitution of the SRP receptor. SRP receptor α subunit (SRα) associates with ER-integrated SRβ to form the SRP receptor and is exposed on the outer membrane surface (35Andrews D.W. Lauffer L. Walter P. Lingappa V.R. J. Cell Biol. 1989; 108: 797-810Crossref PubMed Scopus (46) Google Scholar). This renders SRα susceptible to a mild trypsin treatment, which does not significantly affect any other translocon components, but results in the loss of SRP-dependent targeting. Crucially, the SRP receptor can be reconstituted by the re-addition of small quantities of SRα translated in vitro due to its own SRP-independent route of ER targeting. This method of reconstitution can result in the recovery of up to 78% of translocation activity. β-lactamase was used as a convenient positive control for SRα dependence due to its cleavable signal sequence. Protease-protected fragments were analyzed as a reliable measure of membrane integration. Fig. 2 B shows that trypsin-treated microsomes retained their ability to bind radiolabeled SRα (major protected fragments of 10 kDa and 14k Da; Fig. 2 B, lane 1), but were unable to support significant translocation of oleosin or β-lactamase (Fig.2 B, lanes 3 and 5). However, pre-translation with SRα caused a significant increase in the ability of the trypsinized membranes to translocate both oleosin and β-lactamase (Fig. 2 B, lanes 4 and6). SRα incorporated less efficiently into reconstituted microsomes (Fig. 2 B, lane 2), presumably due to the reduction in the available SRβ partner to which it binds. These results demonstrate that oleosin can be targeted to the ER membrane by the SRP-dependent pathway, and by implication suggests that it uses the Sec61 translocon for its integration. The most important feature of an ER signal sequence is the hydrophobic core, h (36Martoglio B. Dobberstein B. Trends Cell Biol. 1998; 8: 410-415Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (432) Google Scholar). This comprises typically between 5 and 15 residues in a cleavable signal sequence and ∼20 residues in a signal-anchor. It is possible to identify several putative h regions within the H domain of oleosin due to its overall hydrophobicity. Many signal sequences are preceded by positively charged residues (n region). Therefore, the region of oleosin chosen for investigation was the H domain and the preceding charged region in the N domain. First, the ability of the oleosin H domain to integrate independently was investigated. A segment beginning with the charged region preceding the H domain and ending before the C domain (denoted HOLEO) was isolated and translated in vitro. We found that HOLEO is associated with microsomes (Fig. 3 A,lane 1) and is protected from proteinase K (Fig.3 A, lane 3), indicating efficient membrane integration. The small size reduction of the polypeptide is probably due to access of the protease to the residual short portion of N domain. Clearly, the H domain is sufficient for membrane insertion, but it was still possible that the N or C domains could also contain ER targeting information. Therefore, a construct lacking the hydrophobic region was generated. This construct NPCOLEO, consists of the central proline knot motif flanked by N and C domains. Upon translation in vitro, NPCOLEO was mostly associated with microsomes (Fig. 3 A, lane 2), yet treatment with proteinase K results in almost complete loss of detectable fragments (Fig. 3 A, lane 4). The smaller product observed before protease treatment is likely to be the product of downstream initiation, as demonstrated previously for native oleosin (14Abell B.M. Holbrook L.A. Abenes M. Murphy D.J. Hills M.J. Moloney M.M. Plant Cell. 1997; 9: 1481-1493Crossref PubMed Scopus (141) Google Scholar). This protease sensitivity demonstrates that although NPCOLEO binds to microsomal membranes, probably due to its charged and amphipathic nature, it is not integrated into the membrane. To refine the identification of oleosin ER targeting signal(s), individual portions of the H domain were isolated and analyzed for their targeting ability. OSS3 includes the N-terminal portion of the H domain (H(N)) and the preceding charged region in the N domain; OSS4 includes the C-terminal portion of the H domain (H(C)) and the preceding proline knot motif. Both segments were fused to β-glucuronidase (GUS) as a non-ER-targeted reporter for use in vitro (37Jefferson R.A. Plant Mol. Biol. Rep. 1987; 5: 387-405Crossref Scopus (3992) Google Scholar). Membrane integration was tested by pelleting and by further carbonate extraction. Fig.4 A shows that OSS3G and OSS4G are both capable of significant microsomal association, compared with the non-targeted GUS (ntGUS), which does not associate with the membrane fraction (compare supernatant and pellet fractions). Similar experiments with β-lactamase and preprolactin show that the proportion of polypeptide targeted to membranes is comparable (data not shown), confirming a high efficiency of signal sequence activity for OSS3 and OSS4. Furthermore, carbonate extraction of the membrane pellets does not significantly affect membrane association of OSS3G and OSS4G, in contrast to a complete loss of ntGUS (lanes 11–13). The targeting activity of OSS3 and OSS4 provides evidence for the presence of at least two independent signal sequences present within the H domain. To pinpoint signal sequence information, OSS3G was modified by 1) substitution of charged residues to create OSS6G and 2) polarization of the N-terminal hydrophobic region to create OSS7G (S1 and S2 mutations respectively; see Fig. 1 B). γ-Glutamylcysteine synthetase (γ-GCS, glutamate-cysteine ligase), which catalyzes the first and rate-limiting step in glutathione biosynthesis, is present in many prokaryotes and in virtually all eukaryotes. Although all eukaryotic γ-GCS isoforms examined to date are rapidly inhibited by buthionine sulfoximine (BSO), most reports indicate that bacterial γ-GCS is resistant to BSO. We have confirmed the latter finding with Escherichia coliγ-GCS under standard assay conditions, showing both decreased initial binding affinity for BSO and a reduced rate of BSO-mediated inactivation compared with mammalian isoforms. We also find that substitution of Mn2+ for Mg2+ in assay mixtures increases both the initial binding affinity of BSO and the rate at which BSO causes mechanism-based inactivation. Similarly, the specificity of E. coli γ-GCS for its amino acid substrates is broadened in the presence of Mn2+, and the rate of reaction for some very poor substrates is improved. These results suggest that divalent metal ions have a role in amino acid binding to E. coli γ-GCS. Electron paramagnetic resonance (EPR) studies carried out with Mn2+ show that E. coli γ-GCS binds two divalent metal ions;Kd values for Mn2+ are 1.1 μm and 82 μm, respectively. Binding ofl-glutamate or l-BSO to the two Mn2+/γ-GCS species produces additional upfield and downfield X-band EPR hyperfine lines at 45 G intervals, a result indicating that the two Mn2+ are spin-coupled and thus apparently separated by 5 Å or less in the active site. Additional EPR studies in which Cu2+ replaced Mg2+ or Mn2+ suggest that Cu2+ is bound by one N and three O ligands in the γ-GCS active site. The results are discussed in the context of the catalytic mechanism of γ-GCS and its relationship to the more fully characterized glutamine synthetase reaction. γ-Glutamylcysteine synthetase (γ-GCS, glutamate-cysteine ligase), which catalyzes the first and rate-limiting step in glutathione biosynthesis, is present in many prokaryotes and in virtually all eukaryotes. Mulcahy R.T. Adv. Enzymol. Rel. Areas Mol. Biol. 1999; 73: 209-267PubMed Google Scholar, 2Meister A. Anderson M.E. Ann. Rev. Biochem. 1983; 52: 711-760Crossref PubMed Scopus (5925) Google Scholar, 3Meister A. Cancer Res. 1994; 54: 1969s-1975sPubMed Google Scholar). Glutathione is more narrowly distributed among bacteria (4Newton G.L. Fahey R.C. Viña J. Glutathione: Metabolism and Physiological Functions. CRC Press, Inc., Boca Raton, FL1990: 69-77Google Scholar), and its function in bacteria is less well defined. Mulcahy R.T. Adv. Enzymol. Rel. Areas Mol. Biol. 1999; 73: 209-267PubMed Google Scholar, 2Meister A. Anderson M.E. Ann. Rev. Biochem. 1983; 52: 711-760Crossref PubMed Scopus (5925) Google Scholar). Hayward M.L. Griffith O.W. Anal. Biochem. 1991; 194: 268-277Crossref PubMed Scopus (48) Google Scholar), to inhibit E. coli γ-GCS. In confirmation of most (18Romero M.J.M. Canada A.T. Toxicol. Appl. Pharmacol. 1991; 111: 485-495Crossref PubMed Scopus (18) Google Scholar), but not all (27Huang C.S. Moore W.R. Meister A. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 1988; 85: 2464-2468Crossref PubMed Scopus (107) Google Scholar), literature reports, we find that BSO is a relatively poor inhibitor of bacterial γ-GCS, particularly in the presence of physiological levels of l-glutamate. We have therefore investigated the interactions of E. coli γ-GCS with l-S-BSO and with its amino acid substrates and various substrate analogs in an effort to elucidate binding interactions that might be exploited in designing novel, more potent inhibitors. We find that substrate specificity depends on the divalent metal ion present (i.e. Mg2+ or Mn2+), a result suggesting that metal ions have a role in the binding of amino acid substrates and inhibitors in addition to their expected role in ATP binding. Electron paramagnetic resonance (EPR) studies carried out with Mn2+ show that E. coli γ-GCS contains two active site divalent metal ions. Binding of l-glutamate or l-S-BSO induces additional 45 G coupling within the EPR spectra indicative of Mn2+-Mn2+ coupling through spin exchange. These results are discussed in terms of the mechanism of action of E. coli γ-GCS.DISCUSSIONγ-Glutamylcysteine synthetase has been identified in a wide range of organisms including bacteria, protozoa, fungi, plants, insects, and mammals. Cloning studies show a moderate to high degree of amino acid sequence homology among the mammalian, insect, yeast, and protozoal γ-GCS isoforms, but little homology between those enzymes and the γ-GCS of either plants or bacteria (1Griffith O.W. Mulcahy R.T. Adv. Enzymol. Rel. Areas Mol. Biol. 1999; 73: 209-267PubMed Google Scholar). Notwithstanding these differences and additional marked differences in quaternary structure, all γ-GCS, including those of plants and bacteria, are presumed to catalyze a two-step ligase reaction mechanistically similar to that established for rat γ-GCS (Equations 3 and 4). Supporting that view, most γ-GCS isoforms are reported to be strongly inhibited by BSO, a mechanism-based inhibitor that initially binds as an analog of the tetrahedral intermediate formed whenl-γ-glutamylphosphate and l-α-aminobutyrate react in the second step of the normal γ-GCS reaction (1Griffith O.W. Mulcahy R.T. Adv. Enzymol. Rel. Areas Mol. Biol. 1999; 73: 209-267PubMed Google Scholar, 26Campbell E.B. Hayward M.L. Griffith O.W. Anal. Biochem. 1991; 194: 268-277Crossref PubMed Scopus (48) Google Scholar, 38Griffith O.W. J. Biol. Chem. 1982; 257: 13704-13712Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar). Once bound, l-S-BSO is phosphorylated on its sulfoximine N in a reaction that mimics phosphorylation of the γ-carboxylate of l-glutamate in the first step of the normal γ-GCS reaction. Studies with rat γ-GCS show that phosphorylated l-S-BSO is tightly bound to the active site, causing essentially irreversible inhibition (26Campbell E.B. Hayward M.L. Griffith O.W. Anal. Biochem. 1991; 194: 268-277Crossref PubMed Scopus (48) Google Scholar, 38Griffith O.W. J. Biol. Chem. 1982; 257: 13704-13712Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar). Mechanism-based inhibition by l-S-BSO thus mimics key aspects of both the first and second steps of the γ-GCS reaction, and irreversible inhibition by BSO is therefore good evidence for mechanistic similarity between any γ-GCS isoform inhibited by BSO and the well characterized rat γ-GCS.L­glutamate+MgATP→L­γ­glutamylphosphate+MgADPEquation 3 L=γ­glutamylphosphate+L­α­aminobutyrate→Equation 4 L­γ­glutamyl­L­α­aminobutyrate+PiIt was in this context that we were interested in the possible discrepancy between a report that BSO inhibits E. coliγ-GCS comparably to rat γ-GCS (27Huang C.S. Moore W.R. Meister A. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 1988; 85: 2464-2468Crossref PubMed Scopus (107) Google Scholar) and other reports showing that exposure of intact E. coli to BSO does not cause inhibition of GSH synthesis or GSH depletion (18Romero M.J.M. Canada A.T. Toxicol. Appl. Pharmacol. 1991; 111: 485-495Crossref PubMed Scopus (18) Google Scholar). As shown in Fig. 1, we find that l-S-BSO can fully inhibit E. coli γ-GCS, but, at all concentrations tested, the rate of inactivation is much slower than is seen with human (this work) or rat (38Griffith O.W. J. Biol. Chem. 1982; 257: 13704-13712Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar) γ-GCS. Weaker initial binding and a slower rate of sulfoximine phosphorylation both contribute to the slower rate of inactivation. Thus, l-S-BSO binds to E. coliγ-GCS with a Kd value of 66 μmwhereas human γ-GCS is inhibited so rapidly by 5 μm and higher concentrations of l-S-BSO that meaningfulKd values could not be determined. In earlier studies with rat γ-GCS, it was estimated that the active diastereomer of BSO had an apparent Kd of 25 μm in the presence of 5 mm l-glutamate, a ligand which competes with the sulfoximine for initial binding (38Griffith O.W. J. Biol. Chem. 1982; 257: 13704-13712Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar). Those studies suggest that in the absence of l-glutamate the actual Kd for l-S-BSO would be <8 μm, but rapid kinetic studies are necessary to make an accurate determination.Once bound to E. coli γ-GCS,l-S-BSO reacts relatively slowly with ATP to form the tightly bound phosphorylated derivative. We findkinact = 0.30 min−1(t½ ∼2.3 min) for E. coli γ-GCS, a value which is <8% of the kinact determined earlier for rat γ-GCS in the presence of l-glutamate (kinact = 3.9 min−1;t½ ∼11 s) (38Griffith O.W. J. Biol. Chem. 1982; 257: 13704-13712Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar). Whether weak binding and slow phosphorylation of l-S-BSO account for its inability to deplete E. coli of GSH requires additional studies. In preliminary experiments, we have confirmed an earlier report that BSO is taken up by E. coli(27Huang C.S. Moore W.R. Meister A. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 1988; 85: 2464-2468Crossref PubMed Scopus (107) Google Scholar), 3M.A. Hayward and O.W. Griffith, unpublished data. but the intracellular concentration of l-S-BSO relative tol-glutamate and the rate at which E. coliconsume or release GSH have not yet been determined.ATP-dependent ligases such as γ-GCS require a divalent metal ion, typically Mg2+, to help bind and orientate the triphosphate portion of the nucleotide in the active site. Such ions may also help to orientate and deprotonate the substrate nucleophile to which phosphoryl transfer will occur (39Walsh C. Enzymatic Reaction Mechanisms. W. H. Freeman and Co., New York1979: 88-89Google Scholar, 45Reed G.H Markham G.D. Berliner L.T. Reuben J. Biological Magnetic Resonance. Plenum Publishing Corp., New York1984: 73-142Crossref Google Scholar). Although it was earlier reported that E. coli γ-GCS is not active with Mn2+, Co2+, Ca2+, or Zn2+ (29Watanabe K. Murata K. Kimura A. Agric. Biol. Chem. 1986; 50: 1925-1930Google Scholar), we find that highly purified enzyme has substantial activity with Mn2+, Co2+, Cd2+, and Fe2+. Interestingly,Km values for l-glutamate and glutamate analogs are markedly reduced in the presence of Mn2+, suggesting that the divalent metal plays a role inl-glutamate binding. This finding is consistent with the general observation that Mn2+ improves ligand binding over that seen with Mg2+ (47Irving H. Williams R.J.P. J. Chem. Soc. 1953; : 3192-3210Crossref Scopus (1750) Google Scholar). Reaction velocities for most glutamate analogs are reduced in the presence of Mn2+, but the decrease in Vmax is less for the analogs than for l-glutamate itself. α-Methyl-l-glutamate, which shows very poor activity with Mg2+, actually has a higher Vmaxwith Mn2+ than Mg2+.Substitution of Mn2+ for Mg2+ also decreases the Km for l-cysteine and most of its analogs, suggesting that metal ions might also have a role inl-cysteine binding. We do note, however, that the decrease in the Km for l-cysteine itself is small relative to the changes seen for l-glutamate and its analogs. For analogs having >5% the activity ofl-cysteine, Vmax values were uniformly higher with Mg2+ than Mn2+, but for very poorly reactive substrates, Vmax values were higher with Mn2+. The latter observation is of interest because we find that kinact forl-S-BSO is higher in the presence of Mn2+. It was earlier proposed that the S-butyl moiety of l-S-BSO occupies thel-cysteine binding site of γ-GCS (38Griffith O.W. J. Biol. Chem. 1982; 257: 13704-13712Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar), and our results are thus consistent with the view that l-S-BSO reacts as a poor γ-GCS substrate that is phosphorylated relatively slowly.E. coli glutamine synthetase has no overall amino acid sequence homology with either E. coli or mammalian γ-GCS, but it catalyzes a mechanistically similar reaction in whichl-glutamate is first phosphorylated by ATP and the resulting γ-glutamylphosphate is then attacked by ammonia to form glutamine (in addition to ADP and Pi) (48Meister A. Methods Enzymol. 1985; 113: 185-199Crossref PubMed Scopus (133) Google Scholar).2 The enzyme is irreversibly inhibited by thel-S-diastereomer of methionine sulfoximine (49Manning J.M. Moore S. Rowe W.B. Meister A. Biochemistry. 1969; 8: 2681-2685Crossref PubMed Scopus (110) Google Scholar), which is the same diastereomer of methionine sulfoximine that potently inhibits rat γ-GCS (50Richman P.G. Orlowski M. Meister A. J. Biol. Chem. 1973; 248: 6684-6690Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar). Correspondingly, rat (26Campbell E.B. Hayward M.L. Griffith O.W. Anal. Biochem. 1991; 194: 268-277Crossref PubMed Scopus (48) Google Scholar), human (this work), and E. coli γ-GCS (this work) are all inhibited byl-S-BSO, suggesting that the relative orientation of substrates is similar in the active sites of glutamine synthetase and mammalian and E. coli γ-GCS.
